thread.title: Knicks stand out among New York franchises rated low by ESPN
thread.title_full: Knicks stand out among New York franchises rated low by ESPN - NY Daily News

author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Knicks stand out among New York franchises rated low by ESPN
text:
Alex Brandon/AP Guard Langston Galloway and coach Derek Fisher hope to improve the Knicks’ poor standing. ESPN just gave a new reason for some New Yorkers to complain about the city’s sports scene — not one local team finished in the top 70 in the network’s rankings of the major sports franchises.
The rankings, which rate the 122 major North American pro sports franchises, were compiled by ESPN The Magazine .
For the second year in a row, the lowly Knicks finished in second-to-last place, checking in at No. 121.
FOLLOW THE DAILY NEWS SPORTS ON FACEBOOK. "LIKE" US HERE
RICH SCHULTZ/AP How will coach Jack Capuano and his Islanders fare in their first season at Barclays Center? The recently relocated Islanders rated the highest on the fan-determined list — with the Barclays Center's newest residents coming in at No. 73.
The Rangers and Giants were close behind at 75th and 76th, respectively, with the No. 90 Yankees being the fourth and final area team to crack the top 100.
The Mets, who were scheduled to play game 4 of the NLDS on Tuesday night, did not make an appearance until No. 102. After them, the Nets were ranked 111th and the Jets 116th.
ESPN.com The eight categories ESPN considered when building the rankings. The rankings were determined on the basis of eight categories, each of which carried different weights: affordability (11.3% weight), coaching (3.2%), fan relations (25%), ownership (13.1%), players (14.6%), stadium experience (9.8%), title track (4.6%) and bang for the buck (18.3%).
For the first seven categories, ESPN surveyed 1,014 fans on what they want from their teams, with the poll covering 25 areas — "from 'has honest ownership' to 'connects me to information I want about the team online or via mobile devices.'"
Fans were also asked to rate their teams in those 25 areas, with more than 100,000 responding.
CHECK OUT THE NEW APP: GET THE DAILY NEWS ON ANDROID OR IOS
Julie Jacobson/AP Tanner Glass, Henrik Lundqvist and the Rangers are coming off an appearance in the Eastern Conference finals. Tony Gutierrez/AP Eli Manning has the Giants atop the NFC East with a 3-2 record. Chris O'Meara/AP Brian McCann and the Yankees made the postseason but lost in the wild card game. Lenny Ignelzi/AP Jacob deGrom and the Mets are on the verge of going to the NLCS. Paul Sancya/AP Nets coach Lionel Hollins is preparing for the 2015-16 basketball season. Matt Dunham/AP Nick Mangold, Brandon Marshall and the Jets are 3-1 so far. Previous Next Enlarge As for the "bang for your buck category," ESPN relied on calculations developed with the University of Oregon's Warsaw Sports Marketing Center to "figure out how efficiently teams convert the money fans spend into on-field wins (including the postseason)."
Breaking the latest rankings down by league, the Islanders and Rangers were 21st and 23rd in the NHL; the Giants and Jets were 17th and 30th in the NFL; the Yankees and Mets were 22nd and 26th in MLB; and the Nets and Knicks were 28th and 30th in the NBA.
With the exception of the 32-team NFL, each league is comprised of 30 franchises.
The Islanders made the biggest improvement from 2014, jumping 43 spots from No. 116. The Nets suffered the biggest slide, falling 35 slots from No. 76.
But for all the volatility at the Barclays Center, there was next to none at Madison Square Garden: The Knicks still stink.
memery@nydailynews.com
